section.title: Prerequisite Knowledge

statement.p:
Let S be a set of numbers.
Any nonzero element of S is a polynomial of degree zero.
Let n be a positive integer and x \notin S, x \neq 0. A polynomial of degree n in x is any expression that can be written in the form q(x)\cdot x + b, where b is an element of S and q(x) is a polynomial of degree n-1 over S.

remark.p: In the remainder of this chapter, if we simply refer to a polynomial, you can assume that it is a polynomial over any field.

section.p: What is the Fundamental theorem of Algebra?
What does it mean to divide one polynomial by a second (nonzero) polynomial? What is the result?
If p(x) and q(x) are polynomials of degree m and n, how are the degrees of p(x) + q(x), p(x)q(x),p(q(x)) and q(p(x)) related to m and n?
Why is it customary to consider the degree of the zero polynomial to be undefined?
Let p(x) be a polynomial and \alpha a number. What is the relationship between p(\alpha ) and division of p(x) by x - \alpha?
If the degree of p(x) is n with roots x_1, x_2, \ldots , x_n (possibly repeated). How are a_0, a_{n-2} and a_{n-1} related to the roots of p(x)?

statement.p: If z=a + b i is a complex number then \bar{z}= a -b i is its complex conjugate. Prove that for any two complex numbers z and w, \overline{z+w}=\bar{z}+\bar{w} and \overline{z\cdot w}=\bar{z}\cdot \bar{w}. The second identity implies \overline{z^n}=\bar{z}^n for all positive integers n, which can be proven by induction, but don{'}t do this.

Let p(x) be a polynomial over the real numbers. \\ (a) Prove that if z=a + b i is a root of p(x), then \bar{z}= a -b i is also a root of p(x).\\ (b) Prove that p(x) can be factored into a product of linear and quadratic polynomials with real coefficients.

This exercise can initiate a more general discussion of conditions under which polynomial interpolation is possible
Given three real numbers x_0 \lt x_1 \lt x_2, and three more real numbers y_0, y_1, y_2, not necessarily distinct, does there always exist a unique polynomial, p(x), of degree less than or equal to 2 such that p\left(x_0\right)=y_0, p\left(x_1\right)=y_1, and p\left(x_2\right)=y_2?
Same as part (a) but replace p\left(x_2\right)=y_2 with p'\left(x_2\right)=y_2.
Same as part (a) but replace p\left(x_1\right)=y_1 with p'\left(x_1\right)=y_1.
Prove that there is no polynomial with integer coefficients P(x) with the property that P(7) = 5 and P(15) = 9.
Find all polynomials, p(x), with real coefficients satisfying the equation p(x-1)p(x+1) = p(p(x)).
Find all polynomials P(x) with the property that P(x) is a multiple of its second derivative, P\text{''}(x).

The zeros of the polynomial P(x) = x^3 - 10x + 11 are u, v, and w. Determine the value of \arctan u + \arctan v + \arctan w.
Hint:
Determine all polynomials P(x) such that P\left(x^2+1\right)=P(x)^2+1 and P(0)=0.
